title: Ticket #4990: condor_submit -dump produces ClassAd unparsable by python bindings
description:
Tom Downs writes: 

I am working on a script involving condor_submit and the HTCondor python
bindings. I would like to check that the accounting group in a job classad
is, in fact, a valid accounting group according to the schedd

Before submission, I would like to use "condor_submit -dump" to produce the
classad, import it in Python and do a simple comparison.

Dumping the submit file below (on SL6) produces a classad file with
trailing blank lines.

e.g. condor_submit -dump - sleep.sub

###
Executable = sleep.sh
Universe = vanilla
Error = sleep.err
Output = sleep.out
Log = sleep.log
getEnv = True
notification = Complete
notify_user = tpdownes@gravity.phys.uwm.edu

Queue 1
###

Unless these blank lines are removed, this python command will fail:

ad=classad.parseOld(open('bla'))

I would call this a bug in both condor_submit and the python bindings, but
more so in the python bindings. It would also be nice if it were clarified
whether condor_submit should be producing the "new" ClassAd format.

And followed up with: 

   - Are you able to reproduce this bug?
   - Where do you consider to be a bug?
   - Will condor_submit always -dump in the "old" ClassAd format?
   - Is this dump guaranteed to capture the full job ClassAd as would have
   been submitted in the absence of the -dump option?
remarks:
2015-Apr-07 15:14:55 by tlmiller:
Assigned to you, TJ, because GregT thought you'd been working on condor_q -dump recently. Feel free to make a subticket for fixing the Python bindings, if necessary, and assign it to whoever's appropriate. Thanks.

2015-Apr-07 16:58:44 by johnkn:
This is not a bug because -dump is going to STDOUT. along with the normal output of condor_submit

2015-Apr-07 20:35:45 by bbockelm:
Note you might want to use classad.parseOldAds() instead of classad.parseOld(). The former method is more tolerant of excess newline characters (as that's the separator between multiple classads).

2015-Apr-08 15:39:58 by johnkn:
Tom Downes says: I am not able to comment on the ticket but condor_submit -dump goes to a file or stdout. Either way it produces a completely blank line before EOF.

2015-Apr-08 15:48:56 by johnkn:
Tom, a single blank line at the end of -dump is valid because multiple ads are (potentially) possible. I would say that the bug is that python classad reader doesn't properly handle blank lines. In fact, the python classad reader that expects to see only a single ad should handle any number of blank lines.

2015-Apr-08 16:24:34 by johnkn:
Other questions:

Q: Will condor_submit always -dump in the "old" Classad format?

A: yes

Q: Is this dump guaranteed to capture the full job Classad as would have been submitted in the absence of the -dump option?

A: no. The processing logic in condor_submit is a bit different. In particular it can spit out attributes would would never actually be sent to the schedd when you Queue N and N > 1. Any line of the submit file that refers to $(Cluster) or $(Process) will be wrong.

The new -dry-run argument for condor_submit (new for 8.3.5) is guraranteed to be the same as the attributes that would be sent to the schedd, with the exception of ClusterId which will be set to a simulated value - currently always 1 - so once again, any line in the submit file that refers to $(Cluster) will be wrong. -dry-run is closer to what you want than -dump is though.

2015-Apr-13 19:42:08 by bbockelm:
Hi TJ,

I'm a bit nervous about the posted patch. That would accept something like: 

FOO = 1

BAR = 2

and parse that as a single ClassAd, right? I think that input such as the above should be ignored - or only parsed into a single ad, [FOO = 1;].

My preference would be to have the method only ignore trailing empty lines. Thoughts?

2015-Apr-14 09:59:58 by bbockelm:
After a discussion with TJ, here's the current proposal:

  • parse/parseOld is a flawed API because it isn't explicit about what to do in the presence of multiple classads.
    • For example, parse silently ignores text after the ad. parseOld throws an exception.
    • This is made worse because old classads doesn't have a well-defined format; the semantics of empty lines depends on the context. Sometimes they signify separators between multiple ads; sometimes they are ignored.
  • Accordingly, we propose to deprecate parse and replace with two new functions:
    • parseNext takes a file-like object and returns the next ad, advancing the file pointer to the end of the next ad.
    • parseOne takes a string and parses the entire string as one classad. In the presence of multiple ads or blank space, continue to merge the ads together until the entire string is consumed.
  • Since old-style ads don't have a well-defined format, we should ignore any unparseable lines in parseOldClassAds(). This will allow us to handle the output of the history file and condor_q -g -l.

While the functions will be implemented in the python library, they will be equivalent to the following python code: 

def parse(text):
    warnings.warn("parse is deprecated; use parseAds instead.", DeprecationWarning)
    return classad.parse(text)

def parseOld(text):
    warnings.warn("parseOld is deprecated; use parseAds instead.", DeprecationWarning)
    ad_iter = classad.parseOldAds(text)
    return ad_iter.next()

def parseOldAds(fp):
    warnings.warn("parseOldAds is deprecated; use parseAds(fp, old=True) instead.", DeprecationWarning)
    return classad.parseOldAds(fp)

def parseAds(fp, old=False):
    if old:
        classad.parseOldAds(fp)
    else:
        classad.parseAds(fp)

def parseNext(fp, old=False):
    if isinstance(fp, types.StringType):
        raise ValueError("parseNext must be used with a file-like object; to parse a string into an ad, use parseOne")
    if old:
        ad_iter = classad.parseOldAds(fp)
    else:
        ad_iter = classad.parseAds(fp)
    ad = ad_iter.next()
    return ad

def parseOne(text, old=False):
    if old:
        ad_iter = classad.parseOldAds(text)
    else:
        ad_iter = classad.parseAds(text)
    result = classad.ClassAd()
    for ad in ad_iter:
        result.update(ad)
    return result

2015-Apr-14 11:11:16 by johnkn:
I believe that parseOld should point you at parseOldAds instead of parseNext. It's almost certainly what you really meant to use. 

    warnings.warn("parseOld is deprecated; use parseOldAds instead.",

2015-Apr-14 11:15:53 by johnkn:
As long as we are changing things the naming here parse for new syntax and parseOld for old syntax is misleading. the "old" syntax is almost always the correct choice, but the naming implies otherwise.

2015-Jul-20 16:48:51 by tim:
In writing up the documentation, I noticed that the following example no longer works: 
>>> import classad
>>> import os
>>> fd = os.popen("condor_history -l -match 4")
>>> ads = classad.parseAds(fd)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
IOError: [Errno 29] Illegal seek
>>>
In addition, even if you tell it the type of class ads, it still doesn't work: 
>>> import classad
>>> import os
>>> fd = os.popen("condor_history -l -match 4")
>>> ads = classad.parseAds(fd, classad.Parser.Old)
>>> print [ad["ClusterId"] for ad in ads]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
IOError: [Errno 29] Illegal seek
>>>
So, it works on files. But, it no longer works on streams.
